实战教程：开发 CRUD 功能

Tagtag framework fully supports AI-assisted development through Model Context Protocol (MCP) integration and AI-friendly documentation, enabling you to leverage AI tools to accelerate your development workflow.

Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard for connecting AI assistants (like Claude, ChatGPT, etc.) to external data sources and tools. Through MCP, AI can directly access your project documentation, codebase, and other resources, providing more accurate and relevant assistance.
Tagtag's official documentation has integrated the
module to automatically generate AI-readable documentation files:
: Concise structured documentation optimized for AI to quickly understand the project
: Complete detailed documentation providing in-depth project information
These documents follow the llms.txt standard and can be directly read and parsed by various AI tools and MCP servers.
, providing standard MCP tool interfaces that allow AI assistants to directly access and query documentation content.
In Trae, you need to configure an MCP server to connect to Tagtag's documentation resources.
Create or edit your MCP configuration file (usually in the user configuration directory):
language-json shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
Add Tagtag documentation MCP server configuration

- stock (Integer, stock quantity)
- status (Integer, status: 0-disabled, 1-enabled)
- description (String, product description)
- createTime (LocalDateTime, creation time)
- updateTime (LocalDateTime, update time)
- createBy (String, creator)
- updateBy (String, updater)
- deleted (Integer, logical deletion flag)

<template>
  <a-modal
    :visible="visible"
    :title="title"
    :confirm-loading="loading"
    @ok="handleSubmit"
    @cancel="handleCancel"
  >
    <a-form
      ref="formRef"
      :model="formState"
      :rules="rules"
      :label-col="{ span: 6 }"
      :wrapper-col="{ span: 16 }"
    >
      <a-form-item label="Product Name" name="name">
        <a-input v-model:value="formState.name" placeholder="Please enter product name" />
      </a-form-item>
      
      <a-form-item label="Product Code" name="code">
        <a-input v-model:value="formState.code" placeholder="Please enter product code" />
      </a-form-item>
      
      <a-form-item label="Price" name="price">
        <a-input-number 
          v-model:value="formState.price" 
          :min="0.01"
          :precision="2"
          style="width: 100%"
          placeholder="Please enter price"
        />
      </a-form-item>
      
      <a-form-item label="Stock Quantity" name="stock">
        <a-input-number 
          v-model:value="formState.stock" 
          :min="0"
          style="width: 100%"
          placeholder="Please enter stock quantity"
        />
      </a-form-item>
      
      <a-form-item label="Status" name="status">
        <a-radio-group v-model:value="formState.status">
          <a-radio :value="1">Enabled</a-radio>
          <a-radio :value="0">Disabled</a-radio>
        </a-radio-group>
      </a-form-item>
      
      <a-form-item label="Product Description" name="description">
        <a-textarea 
          v-model:value="formState.description" 
          :rows="4"
          placeholder="Please enter product description"
        />
      </a-form-item>
    </a-form>
  </a-modal>
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref, watch, reactive } from 'vue';
import type { FormInstance } from 'ant-design-vue';
import type { ProductDTO } from '@/api/product';

interface Props {
  visible: boolean;
  title: string;
  formData: Partial<ProductDTO>;
}

interface Emits {
  (e: 'update:visible', value: boolean): void;
  (e: 'submit', data: ProductDTO): void;
}

const props = defineProps<Props>();
const emit = defineEmits<Emits>();

const formRef = ref<FormInstance>();
const loading = ref(false);
const formState = reactive<Partial<ProductDTO>>({});

const rules = {
  name: [{ required: true, message: 'Please enter product name', trigger: 'blur' }],
  code: [{ required: true, message: 'Please enter product code', trigger: 'blur' }],
  price: [{ required: true, message: 'Please enter price', trigger: 'blur' }],
  stock: [{ required: true, message: 'Please enter stock quantity', trigger: 'blur' }],
  status: [{ required: true, message: 'Please select status', trigger: 'change' }]
};

watch(() => props.formData, (data) => {
  Object.assign(formState, data);
}, { immediate: true });

const handleSubmit = async () => {
  try {
    loading.value = true;
    await formRef.value?.validate();
    emit('submit', formState as ProductDTO);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Form validation failed:', error);
  } finally {
    loading.value = false;
  }
};

const handleCancel = () => {
  emit('update:visible', false);
  formRef.value?.resetFields();
};
</script>

Detailed Example: Query RBAC Permission System

// Ask AI
"Please explain the RBAC permission system in Tagtag in detail, including:
1. Permission model design (relationship between users, roles, and permissions)
2. Database table structure
3. Permission validation implementation
4. Frontend permission control
5. Backend permission annotation usage

Please provide relevant code examples"
Please explain the RBAC permission system in Tagtag in detail, including:
Tagtag adopts an RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) permission model, including the following core concepts:
: Collection of permissions, users gain permissions through roles
: Frontend menu and button permission control
language-sql shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

-- User table
CREATE TABLE sys_user (
    id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    username VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    password VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    real_name VARCHAR(50),
    email VARCHAR(100),
    phone VARCHAR(20),
    status TINYINT DEFAULT 1,
    create_time DATETIME,
    update_time DATETIME,
    create_by VARCHAR(50),
    update_by VARCHAR(50),
    deleted TINYINT DEFAULT 0
);

-- Role table
CREATE TABLE sys_role (
    id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    role_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    role_code VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    description VARCHAR(200),
    status TINYINT DEFAULT 1,
    create_time DATETIME,
    update_time DATETIME,
    create_by VARCHAR(50),
    update_by VARCHAR(50),
    deleted TINYINT DEFAULT 0
);

-- Permission table
CREATE TABLE sys_permission (
    id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    permission_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    permission_code VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    resource_type VARCHAR(20),
    resource_url VARCHAR(200),
    description VARCHAR(200),
    create_time DATETIME,
    update_time DATETIME,
    create_by VARCHAR(50),
    update_by VARCHAR(50),
    deleted TINYINT DEFAULT 0
);

-- Menu table
CREATE TABLE sys_menu (
    id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    menu_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    menu_code VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    parent_id BIGINT DEFAULT 0,
    menu_type VARCHAR(20),
    icon VARCHAR(50),
    path VARCHAR(200),
    component VARCHAR(200),
    sort_order INT DEFAULT 0,
    status TINYINT DEFAULT 1,
    create_time DATETIME,
    update_time DATETIME,
    create_by VARCHAR(50),
    update_by VARCHAR(50),
    deleted TINYINT DEFAULT 0
);

-- User role association table
CREATE TABLE sys_user_role (
    id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    user_id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    role_id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    create_time DATETIME,
    UNIQUE KEY uk_user_role (user_id, role_id)
);

-- Role permission association table
CREATE TABLE sys_role_permission (
    id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    role_id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    permission_id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    create_time DATETIME,
    UNIQUE KEY uk_role_permission (role_id, permission_id)
);

-- Role menu association table
CREATE TABLE sys_role_menu (
    id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    role_id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    menu_id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    create_time DATETIME,
    UNIQUE KEY uk_role_menu (role_id, menu_id)
);

language-yaml shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

# .github/workflows/ai-review.yml
name: AI Code Review
on: [pull_request]
jobs:
  review:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - name: AI Review
        run: |
          npx @modelcontextprotocol/cli review \
            --docs http://tagtag.dev/llms.txt
Q: Can I use AI-generated code directly?
A: Not recommended. AI-generated code needs to be manually reviewed, tested, and optimized to ensure it meets project standards and business requirements.
Q: How can I improve AI response quality?
A: Provide clear, specific context information, reference Tagtag documentation structure, and use framework terminology. This way, AI can provide more accurate answers.
Q: What should I do if MCP server connection fails?
A: Check network connection, ensure documentation URL is accessible, review MCP server logs, and verify configuration is correct.
Q: Can I use AI-assisted development offline?
A: Yes. You can download the llms.txt file locally, configure a local MCP server, and achieve offline access.
Tagtag framework supports AI-assisted development through:
: Provides standard llms.txt and llms-full.txt documentation
: Supports Model Context Protocol for easy AI tool access
: Easy for AI to understand and generate code
: Covers all core features and best practices
By properly using AI-assisted development, you can:
